description: A helmet made from a soup pot.  It's not very good protection, but it's better than nothing.
An enclosed helmet made from a stock pot with a blanket stuffed inside to cushion it.  There are strings tied to the handles to help fasten it to your body, but it's hot and unwieldy.
Lightweight sports headgear designed to protect the head while sparring, a frequent sight in boxing gyms and dojos.
A heavy helmet that provides excellent protection from all sorts of damage.  It is labeled as an advanced combat helmet.

pocket_data.description: Pocket for a face shield or a shield visor.
Pocket for a strapped mandible guard.

description: A simple helmet meant to protect the head from fragmentation and impacts.  Its simple steel construction renders it outdated by modern military standards.
//: assuming this is an antique and not a cheap replica

description: A Soviet era tanker helmet.  Its distinctive foam pads are meant to protect a tank driver from bumps against the cramped interior.
An all-encompassing black helmet that covers your entire face and neck, providing excellent protection from all sorts of damage.
A lightweight black helmet that provides excellent protection from all sorts of damage.  It has a military rail system for attachments.

pocket_data.description: Pocket for a face shield or a shield visor.
Pocket for a rail-mounted mandible guard.

description: A distinctive helmet worn by firefighters to protect from falling debris.  More than just a piece of firefighting equipment, it serves as a badge of honor and respect.
A hard plastic helmet that covers the head and ears, designed to protect against a baseball to the head.
A medieval helmet that provides excellent protection for the head, with a Y shaped opening for the face.
A thick foam helmet.  Designed to protect against concussion.

pocket_data.description: Pocket for a strapped mandible guard.

description: A helmet made from the exoskeletons of insects.  Covers the entire head; very light and durable.
A conical iron helm with additional protection for the neck, associated with the Mongol Empire.
A helmet crafted from the carefully cleaned and pruned biosilicified exoskeletons of acidic ants.  Acid-resistant but brittle.
A heavy polycarbonate helmet normally worn by football players.  It comes with a visor to protect the eyes.
An Imperial Roman helmet, with distinct projections protecting the sides of the head.

//: Leaving this at $500 as it's either antique/priceless or player-made/Bartered, leastwise on the initial search.
description: A medieval Japanese helmet with a scowling face mask that provides excellent protection to the entire head and face.
A thick leather helmet that provides excellent protection for the head.
The top part of a large animal skull, equipped with leather straps to secure it on your head.
A cloth liner worn inside a helmet to help keep your head warm in cold climates.  It might also provide some padding against helmets that didn't have any.
A helmet that covers the entire head along with glareproof visors, offering the best protection for when you ride around on your motorcycle.  Activate to raise the visor.
A helmet that covers the entire head along with glareproof visors, offering the best protection when you ride around on your motorcycle.  The visor is raised.  Activate to put down the visor.
A helmet designed to protect from falls and kicks involving horses, has a small peak to protect from glare.
A helmet designed to protect from falls and kicks involving horses.
An early medieval helmet with a projection guarding the nose, to better protect the face without obstructing vision.  Proper Viking gear, unlike the stereotypical horned helm.
A medieval helmet that provides excellent protection to the entire head, at the cost of great encumbrance.
A helmet fashioned in the shape of a cap with a wide brim.  It leaves the face and neck exposed, but offers a bit of cover from glare and rain.
A helmet that looks like a crude bucket with the face cut out.  It comes with a bevor to distribute some of the weight to your shoulders, as well as cloth padding to keep your bell from being rung.
//: The weight assumes one large sheet of about 75cm x 40cm x 1.5mm and one circular sheet with a diameter of 24cm as the crown, and one gambeson hood, but minus the weight of a 25cm x 30cm face cut out.

description: Also called a crash helmet, this piece of headgear is often worn by bikers and extreme sportsmen who prefer to keep their faces uncovered.
A spiked helmet once worn by German military officers.  The spike is ornamental.

pocket_data.description: Pocket for a strapped mandible guard.

description: An ancient Greek bronze helmet that provides excellent protection for the head, with slits for the eyes and mouth.
A solid, single piece closed bronze helmet with a slit for the eyes.
A huge makeshift helmet made from a canning pot.
A helmet made from a soup pot.  It's not very good protection, but it's better than nothing.
A medieval helmet made of steel platemail.  It provides excellent coverage for the head and neck.  Activate it to raise the visor.
A medieval helmet made of steel platemail.  It provides excellent coverage for the head and neck, though at the moment not the face.  Activate it to lower the visor.

A lightweight helmet that is fashioned to look like a real military helmet, but is made of plastic and only protects against BB's and other light threats.  It has a military rail system for attachments.

Pocket for a rail-mounted mandible guard.

description: A style of helmet once used in the Middle East, cylindrical on the top with protection for the nose and ears but nothing lower.
